newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish security council holds key meeting.
newsitem.headline: Turkish security council holds key meeting.

text.p: Turkey's military commanders and political leaders gathered on Friday for much-awaited talks expected to focus on increasing strains between the Islamist-led government and the secular establishment.
Ministers and senior military officials arrived around 3.00 p.m. (1300 GMT) for the National Security Council meeting, which is chaired by President Suleyman Demirel.

Political analysts expect the council, dominated by secularist officers, to issue a warning to Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan and his Welfare Party (RP) that mounting Islamist zeal threatens Turkey's democratic institutions.
Hasan Ekinci, an official of the junior coalition partner True Path Party (DYP), said the session would reduce political tensions.

"RP cannot behave like an opposition party...The task of governments is not to raise tension and stress. God willing, the RP leadership will be more careful after this," Ekinci told reporters before the talks started.

Turkish media have carried reports -- dismissed as untrue by Erbakan and the president's office -- that Demirel warned the Islamist-led coalition in a letter against threatening Turkey's "secularist, democratic (and) republican aims".
The reports, echoing Demirel's recent briefings to newspaper editors, aggravated political tensions over the rising profile of Islamists in the Moslem but secular state.
Those strains have escalated since the army sent tanks on manoeuvres through the Ankara district of Sincan early in February following an Islamist protest there attended by the Iranian ambassador.

"The fear that the rising tension of recent days will lead to the burning of bridges, however unlikely, has been enough to make everybody's hair stand on end in Ankara," wrote Bilal Cetin, columnist for the liberal daily Yeni Yuzyil.
Erbakan was set to speak on state television at 9.00 p.m. (1900 GMT) about the government's performance since coming to power.

Speaking after regular talks with Demirel on Thursday evening, Erbakan dismissed claims that the Islamist-secularist row was undermining his eight-month-old coalition with the True Path's pro-western leader Tansu Ciller.
"Thankfully our government is working harmoniously. The censure motions helped to strengthen our government further," Erbakan told reporters after the talks.

His government this week survived a censure motion challenge from two leftist parties who said the coalition was a threat to the country's secularism. Next week it will face another censure motion debate in parliament proposed by the leading opposition party.

The military's displeasure at Erbakan's efforts to push ahead with Islam-based policies is not expected to result in anything like the three army interventions seen in Turkey since 1960, analysts said.
Financial markets remained steady in cautious trading ahead of the National Security Council meeting.

At the talks, armed forces chief General Ismail Hakki Karadayi was expected to make a speech criticising pro-sharia, or Islamic law, comments by Islamists and by the Iranian ambassador at the anti-Israel protest in Sincan.

Karadayi returned to Turkey on Thursday evening from a trip to Israel as part of strengthening military cooperation between the two countries which has angered Islamists both domestically and abroad, notably in Iran.
Relations between Ankara and Tehran have been soured over the Iranian ambassador's invovlement in the Sincan rally, which led to him being recalled to Iran.

In a sign of further bilateral strains, Turkey's Foreign Ministry said on Thursday it was expelling Iran's consul to the eastern town of Erzurum, following his criticism of reported anti-Iranian comments by a leading Turkish military official.
